newsitem.title: UK: British MPs criticise small firm's big aid deal.
newsitem.headline: British MPs criticise small firm's big aid deal.

text.p: The British Parliament's Public Accounts Committee on Thursday criticised the government's foreign aid department for appointing a small company to administer a project worth more than eight times its own annual turnover.

The committee said in a report that the Overseas Development Administration (ODA) only learned that TecQuipment Limited was such a modest enterprise when it ran into difficulties obtaining a bank guarantee for a 10 million pound loan it advanced.

The ODA agreed in September 1991 to give aid of 23.36 million pounds ($38.25 million) towards a 66.75 million pound project managed by TecQuipment to supply technical equipment for engineering faculties in 28 Turkish universities.

In the year to September 1988, immediately before the application for aid, TecQuipment had made a 402,000 pounds profit on turnover of just over eight million. Its net assets were little more than a million pounds.

"We are disturbed that the Administration did not become aware of TecQuipment's modest financial position until they learned, after having approved the contract, that the company were having problems obtaining a bank guarantee," the report said.
It noted that the guarantee was eventually provided by Fisons Plc, which then gained 10 million pounds in orders under the project.
It said the Administration had pointed out to it that provision of the guarantee could not have allowed Fisons to influence TecQuipment since such a guarantee cannot be withdrawn.
But the committee said it was "concerned" that orders for 23.4 million pounds, of which 3.3 million went to TecQuipment and 2.3 million to Fisons, were placed without competition.
"We note the Administration's evidence that the education equipment sector is highly specialised, with a number of proprietary manufacturers," the report said.
"Nevertheless we expect all publicly-funded procurement to be conducted as far as possible on a competitive basis in order to protect value for money and to act as a safeguard against impropriety."
